cs.SD, cs.CL, cs.SD, cs.LG, cs.AI. 

The paper introduces a neural model for speech synthesis, which falls under the category of natural language processing (NLP). The use of emotional labels suggests that the model is designed to generate speech with specific emotional tones, which is a subfield of NLP known as affective computing. Therefore, the most likely sub-category is cs.SD (Sound), which covers research related to audio and speech processing. 

The paper also mentions the use of the Tacotron model, which is a popular end-to-end neural model for speech synthesis. This suggests that the paper could also fall under the sub-category of cs.CL (Computation and Language), which covers research related to natural language processing and machine learning. 

The paper also addresses the exposure bias problem and irregularity of the attention alignment, which are common issues in neural models. This suggests that the paper could also fall under the sub-category of cs.LG (Machine Learning), which covers research related to machine learning algorithms and techniques. 

Finally, the paper uses context vectors and residual connections, which are common techniques in deep learning. This suggests that the paper could also fall under the sub-category of cs.AI (Artificial Intelligence), which covers research related to artificial intelligence and machine learning.
